text:
| This article needs to be **updated**. Please help update this article to
reflect recent events or newly available information. _( September 2024)_  
---|---  
  
The **economy of Mongolia** has traditionally been based on agriculture and
livestock. Mongolia also has extensive mineral deposits: copper, coal,
molybdenum, tin, tungsten, and gold account for a large part of industrial
production. Soviet assistance, at its height one-third of gross domestic
product (GDP), disappeared almost overnight in 1990–91, in the time of the
collapse of the Soviet Union. Mongolia was driven into deep recession.

Economic growth picked up in 1997–99 after stalling in 1996 due to a series of
natural disasters and increases in world prices of copper and cashmere. Public
revenues and exports collapsed in 1998 and 1999 due to the repercussions of
the 1997 Asian financial crisis. In August and September 1999, the economy
suffered from a temporary Russian ban on exports of oil and oil products.
Mongolia joined the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 1997. The international
donor community pledged over $300 million per year in the last Consultative
Group Meeting, held in Ulaanbaatar in June 1999. Recently, the Mongolian
economy has grown at a fast pace due to an increase in mining and Mongolia
attained a GDP growth rate of 11.7% in 2013. However, because much of this
growth is export-based, Mongolia is suffering from the global slowdown in
mining caused by decreased growth in China.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Mongolia has traditionally been based on agriculture and livestock, forming the foundation of its economic activities.
• Mongolia possesses extensive mineral deposits, including copper, coal, molybdenum, tin, tungsten, and gold, which constitute a significant portion of its industrial production.

• During the peak period of Soviet assistance, this support accounted for one-third of Mongolia’s gross domestic product (GDP), but it disappeared almost overnight in 1990–91 following the collapse of the Soviet Union.
• The sudden loss of Soviet aid plunged Mongolia into a deep recession in the early 1990s.
• Economic growth in Mongolia resumed and picked up between 1997 and 1999 after a stall in 1996 caused by a series of natural disasters and increases in world prices of copper and cashmere.
• Public revenues and exports collapsed in 1998 and 1999 as a result of the repercussions from the 1997 Asian financial crisis.
• In August and September 1999, Mongolia’s economy was further impacted by a temporary Russian ban on exports of oil and oil products.
• Mongolia became a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 1997, marking a significant step in its integration into the global economy.

• The international donor community pledged over $300 million per year during the last Consultative Group Meeting held in Ulaanbaatar in June 1999, highlighting ongoing international financial support.
• In recent years, Mongolia’s economy has experienced rapid growth primarily due to an increase in mining activities.
• Mongolia achieved a notable GDP growth rate of 11.7% in 2013, reflecting the boom in its mining sector.

• Despite strong growth, Mongolia’s economy faces challenges due to its heavy reliance on export-based growth, making it vulnerable to the global slowdown in mining caused by decreased economic growth in China.

text: Historical development of real GDP per capita in Mongolia
openai_summarised_points: • The historical development of real GDP per capita in Mongolia reflects significant fluctuations influenced by political, economic, and social changes throughout the 20th and 21st centuries.
• During the early 20th century, Mongolia's economy was predominantly agrarian and pastoral, with limited industrialization, resulting in low GDP per capita levels.

• The establishment of the Mongolian People's Republic in 1924 marked the beginning of a centrally planned economy, which initially led to modest growth in GDP per capita through state-led industrial and agricultural development.

• From the 1950s to the 1980s, Mongolia experienced steady increases in real GDP per capita due to Soviet aid, investments in mining, infrastructure, and collectivized agriculture, although growth rates were relatively moderate compared to global standards.
• The collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 precipitated a severe economic crisis in Mongolia, causing a sharp decline in real GDP per capita as state subsidies and trade links were disrupted.

• The transition from a planned economy to a market-oriented system in the 1990s involved significant economic reforms, including privatization and liberalization, which initially resulted in economic contraction and a decrease in GDP per capita.

• By the late 1990s and early 2000s, Mongolia began to recover economically, with real GDP per capita gradually increasing due to improved macroeconomic policies, foreign investment, and growth in mining exports.

• The discovery and development of large mineral deposits, particularly coal, copper, and gold, in the 2000s significantly boosted Mongolia’s GDP per capita, contributing to rapid economic growth and increased national income.

• Despite this growth, real GDP per capita in Mongolia has remained vulnerable to external shocks such as fluctuations in global commodity prices, harsh climatic conditions affecting agriculture, and political instability.

• Statistical data indicate that Mongolia’s real GDP per capita has increased several-fold since the 1990s, reflecting structural economic transformation and integration into the global economy, although income distribution and poverty remain challenges.

text:
The rapid political changes of 1990–91 marked the beginning of Mongolia's
efforts to develop a market economy, but these efforts have been complicated
and disrupted by the dissolution and continuing deterioration of the economy
of the former Soviet Union. Prior to 1991, 80% of Mongolia's trade was with
the former Soviet Union, and 15% was with other Council for Mutual Economic
Assistance (CMEA) countries. Mongolia was heavily dependent upon the former
Soviet Union for fuel, medicine, and spare parts for its factories and power
plants.[_citation needed_]

The former Soviet Union served as the primary market for Mongolian industry.
In the 1980s, Mongolia's industrial sector became increasingly important. By
1989, it accounted for an estimated 34% of material products, compared to 18%
from agriculture. However, minerals, animals, and animal-derived products
still constitute a large proportion of the country's exports. Principal
imports included machinery, petroleum, cloth, and building materials.

In the late 1980s, the government began to improve links with non-communist
Asia and the West, and tourism in Mongolia developed. As of 1 January 1991,
Mongolia and the former Soviet Union agreed to conduct bilateral trade in hard
currency at world prices.

Despite its external trade difficulties, Mongolia has continued to press ahead
with reform. Privatization of small shops and enterprises has largely been
completed in the 1990s, and most prices have been freed. Privatization of
large state enterprises has begun. Tax reforms also have begun, and the barter
and official exchange rates were unified in late 1991.
openai_summarised_points: • The rapid political changes of 1990–91 initiated Mongolia's transition efforts toward developing a market economy, which were complicated and disrupted by the dissolution and ongoing deterioration of the former Soviet Union's economy.

• Prior to 1991, Mongolia's trade was heavily concentrated with the former Soviet Union, accounting for 80% of its trade, while 15% was with other Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CMEA) countries.
• Mongolia was highly dependent on the former Soviet Union for essential imports such as fuel, medicine, and spare parts necessary for its factories and power plants.
• The former Soviet Union was the primary market for Mongolian industrial products during the socialist era.
• In the 1980s, Mongolia's industrial sector grew in significance, and by 1989, industry accounted for an estimated 34% of material products, surpassing agriculture, which contributed 18%.
• Despite industrial growth, Mongolia's exports remained largely composed of minerals, animals, and animal-derived products.
• Mongolia’s principal imports during this period included machinery, petroleum, cloth, and building materials.

• In the late 1980s, the Mongolian government began enhancing economic and diplomatic relations with non-communist Asian countries and Western nations, which contributed to the development of tourism in Mongolia.
• On 1 January 1991, Mongolia and the former Soviet Union agreed to conduct bilateral trade using hard currency at world market prices, marking a significant shift from previous trade arrangements.
• Despite facing external trade challenges, Mongolia continued to pursue economic reforms throughout the 1990s.
• Privatization efforts in Mongolia during the 1990s largely completed the transfer of small shops and enterprises from state to private ownership.
• Most prices in Mongolia were liberalized during this period, moving away from state-controlled pricing mechanisms.
• The privatization process for large state enterprises commenced in the 1990s, indicating a gradual shift toward a market economy.
• Tax reforms were initiated in Mongolia during the early 1990s as part of broader economic restructuring.
• In late 1991, Mongolia unified its barter and official exchange rates, aiming to stabilize and rationalize its currency and trade practices.

text:
Between 1990 and 1993, Mongolia suffered triple-digit inflation, rising
unemployment, shortages of basic goods, and food rationing. During that
period, economic output contracted by one-third. As market reforms and private
enterprise took hold, economic growth began again in 1994–95. Unfortunately,
since this growth was fueled in part by over-allocation of bank credit,
especially to the remaining state-owned enterprises, economic growth was
accompanied by a severe weakening of the banking sector. GDP grew by about 6%
in 1995, thanks to largely to a boom in copper prices. Average real economic
growth leveled off to about 3.5% in 1996–99 due to the 1997 Asian financial
crisis, the 1998 Russian financial crisis, and worsening commodity prices,
especially copper and gold.

Mongolia's gross domestic product (GDP) growth fell from 3.2% in 1999 to 1.3%
in 2000. The decline can be attributed to the loss of 2.4 million livestock in
bad weather and natural disasters in 2000. Prospects for development outside
the traditional reliance on nomadic, livestock-based agriculture are
constrained by Mongolia's landlocked location and lack of basic
infrastructure. Since 1990, more than 1,500 foreign companies from 61
countries have invested[_when?_] a total of $338.3 million in Mongolia. By
2003 private companies made up 70% of Mongolian GDP and 80% of exports.

Until recently, there have been a very few restrictions on foreign investments
during most of Mongolia's post-socialist period. Consequently, mining
industry's contribution to FDI increased to almost 25% in 1999 from zero in
1990.
openai_summarised_points: • Between 1990 and 1993, Mongolia experienced severe economic difficulties including triple-digit inflation, rising unemployment, shortages of basic goods, and food rationing, with economic output contracting by one-third during this period.

• Economic growth resumed in 1994–95 as market reforms and private enterprise began to take hold, although this growth was partly driven by an over-allocation of bank credit, particularly to remaining state-owned enterprises, which led to a significant weakening of the banking sector.
• In 1995, Mongolia's GDP grew by approximately 6%, largely due to a boom in copper prices.

• From 1996 to 1999, average real economic growth slowed to about 3.5%, influenced by external shocks including the 1997 Asian financial crisis, the 1998 Russian financial crisis, and declining commodity prices, especially for copper and gold.
• Mongolia’s GDP growth rate declined from 3.2% in 1999 to 1.3% in 2000, primarily due to the loss of 2.4 million livestock caused by adverse weather conditions and natural disasters in 2000.
• Development prospects outside the traditional nomadic, livestock-based agriculture sector remain limited due to Mongolia’s landlocked geography and lack of basic infrastructure.
• Since 1990, more than 1,500 foreign companies from 61 countries have invested a total of $338.3 million in Mongolia.
• By 2003, private companies accounted for 70% of Mongolia’s GDP and 80% of its exports, reflecting significant privatization and market economy development.
• Throughout most of Mongolia’s post-socialist period, there were very few restrictions on foreign investments, which facilitated growth in foreign direct investment (FDI).
• The mining industry’s share of FDI increased dramatically from zero in 1990 to nearly 25% by 1999, highlighting the sector’s growing importance in attracting foreign capital.

text:
Mongolian factory worker with cashmere Market in Mongolia

Mongolia's reliance on trade with China meant that the 2008 financial crisis
had a major effect, severely stunting the growth of its economy. With the
sharp decrease in metal prices, especially copper (down 65% from July
2008-February 2009), exports of its raw materials withered and by 2009 the
stock market MSE Top-20 registered an all-time low since its dramatic spike in
mid-2007. Just as the economy started to recover, Mongolia was hit by a Zud
over the winter period of 2009–2010, causing many livestock to perish and thus
severely affecting cashmere production which accounts for a further 7% of the
country's export revenues.

According to the World Bank and International Monetary Fund estimates, real
GDP growth reduced from 8% to 2.7% in 2009, and exports shrunk 26% from $2.5Bn
to $1.9Bn before a promisingly steady increase up until 2008. Because of this,
it was projected that between 20,000 and 40,000 fewer Mongolians (0.7% and
1.4% of the population respectively) will be lifted out of poverty, than would
have been the case without the 2008 financial crisis.

In late 2009 and the beginning of 2010, however, the market has begun to
recover once again. Having identified and learnt from its previous economic
instabilities, legislative reform and a tightened fiscal policy promises to
guide the country onwards and upwards. In February 2010, foreign assets were
recorded at USD1,569,449 million. New trade agreements are being formed and
foreign investors are keeping a close eye on the "Asian Wolf".

Mining is the principal industrial activity in Mongolia, making up 30% of all
Mongolian industry. Another important industry is the production of cashmere.
Mongolia is the world's second largest producer of cashmere, with the main
company, Gobi Cashmere, accounting for 21% of world cashmere production as of
2006.

Total export in 2019 was US$7.6 billion.

The 2022 economic growth is expected to be one percent and international
institutions anticipate the economy to speed up by at least six percent in
2023 from expanded commodity exports. A significant commodity export boom is
expected starting from 2023 with new coal rail networks Error in Webarchive
template: Empty url. to China coming online and increased copper production
from Rio Tinto’s underground mine Oyu Tolgoi in southern Mongolia.

In early 2020s, Mongolia's economy, though experiencing growth spurred by
natural resource exports, faces challenges. Over-reliance on mining, rising
debt, inflation, and potential fuel supply disruptions from Russia pose risks
to the country's economic stability despite government efforts in
infrastructure and social programs.
openai_summarised_points: • Mongolia's economy was severely impacted by the 2008 financial crisis due to its heavy reliance on trade with China, leading to a significant slowdown in economic growth.
• The sharp decline in metal prices, particularly copper which fell by 65% between July 2008 and February 2009, caused a drastic reduction in exports of Mongolia's raw materials.
• By 2009, the Mongolian Stock Exchange (MSE) Top-20 index reached an all-time low following a dramatic spike in mid-2007, reflecting the economic downturn.

• The winter period of 2009–2010 saw Mongolia hit by a Zud, a severe weather disaster, resulting in the death of many livestock and severely damaging cashmere production, which contributes approximately 7% to the country's export revenues.

• According to estimates by the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, Mongolia’s real GDP growth fell from 8% in 2008 to 2.7% in 2009, while exports contracted by 26%, decreasing from $2.5 billion to $1.9 billion.
• The 2008 financial crisis was projected to reduce the number of Mongolians lifted out of poverty by between 20,000 and 40,000 individuals, equivalent to 0.7% to 1.4% of the population.
• By late 2009 and early 2010, Mongolia’s market began to recover, supported by legislative reforms and tightened fiscal policies aimed at stabilizing and advancing the economy.
• In February 2010, Mongolia’s foreign assets were recorded at USD 1,569,449 million, indicating growing financial strength.
• New trade agreements were being established, and foreign investors showed increasing interest in Mongolia, often referred to as the "Asian Wolf" due to its economic potential.
• Mining is the dominant industrial sector in Mongolia, accounting for 30% of all industrial activity.

• Cashmere production is another key industry; Mongolia is the world's second-largest producer of cashmere, with the main company, Gobi Cashmere, responsible for 21% of global cashmere production as of 2006.
• Mongolia’s total exports reached US$7.6 billion in 2019, reflecting growth in trade activities.

• Economic growth in 2022 was expected to be around one percent, with international institutions forecasting an acceleration to at least six percent growth in 2023, driven by expanded commodity exports.

• A significant boom in commodity exports was anticipated from 2023 onwards, facilitated by new coal rail networks to China and increased copper production from Rio Tinto’s underground Oyu Tolgoi mine in southern Mongolia.

• In the early 2020s, despite growth fueled by natural resource exports, Mongolia’s economy faced challenges including over-reliance on mining, rising national debt, inflationary pressures, and potential disruptions to fuel supplies from Russia.
• The Mongolian government continued efforts to bolster economic stability through investments in infrastructure and social programs to mitigate these risks.

text:
The term was coined and subsequently popularized by Renaissance Capital in
their report "Mongolia: "Blue-sky opportunity". They state that Mongolia is
set to become the new Asian tiger, or "Mongolian wolf" as they prefer to call
it, and predict "unstoppable" economic growth. With the recent developments in
the mining industry and foreign interest increasing at an astonishing rate, it
is claimed that the 'Wolf Economy' looks ready to pounce. The term's
aggressive title mirrors the country's attitude in the capital markets, and
with newfound mineral prospects it has the chance to retain its title as one
of the world's fastest growing economies.
openai_summarised_points: • The term "Wolf Economy" was coined and popularized by Renaissance Capital in their report titled "Mongolia: 'Blue-sky opportunity'."
• Renaissance Capital predicts that Mongolia is poised to become the new Asian tiger, alternatively referring to it as the "Mongolian wolf."
• The report forecasts "unstoppable" economic growth for Mongolia, driven primarily by recent developments in the mining industry.
• Foreign interest in Mongolia's economy is increasing at an astonishing rate, contributing to the optimistic outlook.
• The aggressive title "Wolf Economy" reflects Mongolia's assertive attitude in capital markets.
• With the discovery of new mineral prospects, Mongolia has the potential to maintain its status as one of the world's fastest growing economies.

text:
Mongolian Stock Exchange

The banking sector is highly concentrated, with five banks controlling about
80% of financial assets as of 2015: Shares of Mongolia's five largest domestic
banks are to be offered to the public for the first time on the soon-to-be
partially privatized Mongolian Stock Exchange.
openai_summarised_points: • As of 2015, Mongolia's banking sector is highly concentrated, with five banks controlling approximately 80% of the country's financial assets.
• Shares of Mongolia's five largest domestic banks are planned to be offered to the public for the first time through the Mongolian Stock Exchange.
• This initiative is part of the partial privatization process of these major banks via the Mongolian Stock Exchange.

text:
* KhasBank \- KhasBank is a community development bank and microfinance institution headquartered in Ulaanbaatar, with a nationwide network of 100 offices and 1309 staff as of June 2012.
* Khan Bank \- Khan Bank has its central office in Ulaanbaatar, where 5 branches are located. It has 24 regional branch offices throughout the country, each of which supervises an additional 15 to 25 smaller branches in its area, totaling 512.
* Golomt Bank \- Golomt Bank started in 1995 and now manages around 23% of the assets in the domestic banking system. Recently begun its stock sales.
* Trade and Development Bank \- TDB was formed in 1990 and is thus the oldest bank in Mongolia. It has a network of 28 branches and settlement centers, 60 ATMs, 1300 POS terminals, and Internet/SMS banking throughout the country. Foreign banks like ING are breaking into the market.
* Other lesser banks are: M-Bank, State bank, Capitron Bank, Arig Bank, Bogd Bank, and Chinggis Bank.

In terms of access to credit, Mongolia ranked 61st out of 189 economies in
accordance with 2015 Ease of Doing Business survey. However, Mongolia had one
of the highest banking branch penetration rates in the world at 1 bank branch
per 15,257 residents as of May 2015.

With a strengthening capital market environment, many foreign and local
investment institutions have begun to establish themselves in Mongolia. The
most prominent local agencies include: TDB Capital Archived 31 December 2019
at the Wayback Machine, Eurasia Capital, Monet Investment Bank, BDSec, MICC
Archived 18 August 2020 at the Wayback Machine, and Frontier Securities.

As a result of rapid urbanization and industrial growth policies under the
communist regime, Mongolia's deteriorating environment has become a major
concern. The burning of soft coal coupled with thousands of factories in
Ulaanbaatar and a sharp increase in individual motorization has resulted in
severe air pollution. Deforestation, overgrazed pastures, and, less recently,
efforts to increase grain and hay production by plowing up more virgin land
have increased soil erosion from wind and rain.
